title: ASR: move IntegerPointer, RealPointer, ... into a boolean argument for Variable
body:
*Original issue*: https://gitlab.com/lfortran/lfortran/-/issues/557

Semantically, being a `pointer` is not really part of the type. For example, in an expression `a+b+c`, if `b` is a real pointer and `a` and `c` are not, what is the type of the result? My understanding is that the result is `real`, of the same `rank`, but it is unspecified whether it is a pointer or not --- to be exact, an expression is always a `value`. Rather, when you write `r = a+b+c`, then you lookup if `r` is a pointer and if so, dereference `r` first before assigning. Just to make sure, I asked at https://fortran-lang.discourse.group/t/is-a-variable-exactly-one-of-pointer-value-or-unspecified/1768.

So `pointer` seems to be on the same level as `value`, which is currently represented in `bool value_attr` in `Variable`. I believe the options are either `pointer`, or `value` or `unspecified`. So we might simply extend it to these three options.
